welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “Which piece of technology from the past century do you think has had the biggest impact on computing today? Why?” Students write a short paragraph and discuss responses as a class.

aim.data: State the agenda and objective: Learn about key milestones in computing history and understand how the field evolved from mechanical to digital systems.

review.data: Connect to prior knowledge of binary and early computing hardware. Prompt: “How might binary representation have been influenced by early computers?”

relevant.data: Mini-lecture covering major milestones: Babbage's Analytical Engine, Ada Lovelace's algorithms, ENIAC, transistors, the microprocessor, personal computers, the World Wide Web, and mobile computing. Use a growing timeline visual as you teach.

interactive.data: Group activity: Students research 2–3 assigned milestones using computers and complete a timeline summary (what happened, who was involved, why it's important). They post findings to a collaborative class timeline (Google Slides, Padlet, or Jamboard).

ownership.data: Individual journal entry: “If you could go back in time and be part of one computing milestone, which would you choose and why?” Encourage thoughtful historical reasoning.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket: “What is one invention or moment in computing history that surprised you the most today?” Collected via Google Form or class share-out.

supplies.data: Computers with internet access, projector and slides, collaborative timeline tool (Google Slides, Padlet, etc.), timeline template or worksheet (digital or printed).
